author: Sun Tzu
summary: Prolonged warfare drains resources and weakens the state. A wise general forages on the enemy, understanding that speed and efficiency are essential. Victory, not lengthy campaigns, should be the goal.
key_takeaways: Prolonged warfare exhausts resources and benefits no one.
A wise general forages on the enemy - one cartload of enemy provisions equals twenty of your own.
Let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns.

questions.question: According to Sun Tzu, what is the primary danger of prolonged warfare?

options.text: Resources are exhausted and the state is weakened

questions.explanation: Sun Tzu warns: 'There is no instance of a country having benefited from prolonged warfare.' When weapons are dulled and strength exhausted, other chieftains will take advantage of your weakness.

questions.question: Why does Sun Tzu say that one cartload of the enemy's provisions is equivalent to twenty of one's own?

options.text: Transporting supplies over distance is expensive and depleting, while foraging locally is efficient
The enemy always has more food

questions.explanation: Contributing to maintain an army at a distance causes the people to be impoverished. The cost of transportation and logistics makes local foraging vastly more efficient than long supply lines.

questions.question: How does Sun Tzu's advice about avoiding prolonged warfare apply to modern business competition?

options.text: Companies should always fight price wars until competitors are destroyed
Quick, decisive actions are often better than drawn-out competitive battles that drain resources from all parties
Business competition is not like warfare at all

questions.explanation: Just as prolonged warfare weakens all parties, prolonged business battles (like price wars) often harm everyone involved. Swift, decisive strategic moves that achieve objectives efficiently are preferable to drawn-out conflicts.
